channel.title: Jaaa..new car
channel.description:
What do you think. I picked it up for $6,000 under kbb value and it has no scratches or anything
2005 Acura RL 300HP V6 3.5L 5 Speed Triptronic Auto/Manual with Paddle Shifters ....Basically loaded with everything and got it for a really really good price
[IMG]http://i286.photobucket.com/albums/ll113/mwiebelhaus/Acura%20RL/IMG_1165.jpg[/img] [IMG]http://i286.photobucket.com/albums/ll113/mwiebelhaus/Acura%20RL/IMG_1189.jpg[/img] [IMG]http://i286.photobucket.com/albums/ll113/mwiebelhaus/Acura%20RL/IMG_1186.jpg[/img] [IMG]http://i286.photobucket.com/albums/ll113/mwiebelhaus/Acura%20RL/IMG_1181.jpg[/img] [IMG]http://i286.photobucket.com/albums/ll113/mwiebelhaus/Acura%20RL/IMG_1180.jpg[/img] [IMG]http://i286.photobucket.com/albums/ll113/mwiebelhaus/Acura%20RL/IMG_1173.jpg[/img] [IMG]http://i286.photobucket.com/albums/ll113/mwiebelhaus/Acura%20RL/IMG_1169.jpg[/img] [IMG]http://i286.photobucket.com/albums/ll113/mwiebelhaus/Acura%20RL/IMG_1196.jpg[/img]

item.title: Jaaa..new car
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

On a side note I finally learned how to use the sportshift mode and it greatly increased my 0-60 by about 1.5 seconds from using automatic. Just put it in gear one take off, upshift 300rpm’s before redline then do it again.

Read full topic

item.title: Jaaa..new car
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

In all honesty, my car does about 23.5 miles per gallon, when I’m driving at a constant speed. I’ll probably get rid of it once I finish my internship though. I can’t afford a car that’s large enough so I can sit in it comfortably, which is why I bought this one. I get enough money to pay for fuel though, so that’s not a problem.

Read full topic

item.title: Jaaa..new car
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

I got 29.1 mpg on my last tank which I think is pretty good considering its rated at 18/26 but I haven’t been hitting the accelerator at the green lights either like usual so that could factor in.

Read full topic

item.title: Jaaa..new car
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Hehe, are you serious? None of my cars get that good of gas mileage. Actually, we recently got my wife a 2008 Chrysler PT Cruiser, and I think it gets near 28mpg, which is amazing.

The rest of my vehicles get something like:
1989 Chevy S10 4x4 - 350 V8 - 15mpg
1990 Chevy 454SS - 454 V8 - 12mpg
1992 Dodge D350 - 360 V8 - 14mpg
1973 Plymouth Satellite - 400 V8 - 10mpg

Those are general estimates, it varies slightly. Except the 454, it has always got 12 regardless.

Read full topic

item.title: Jaaa..new car
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Moparisthebest:

the EPA estimated gas mileage is 17 in town and 24 on the highway, but generally it gets 20-22ish. That’s really good for such a powerful, large car

Woah, I don’t think I could drive a car with that low MPG.

Read full topic

item.title: Jaaa..new car
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

.Unlimited:

How about comparing MPG on all of those cars.

Actually, like I said, the 5.7 Hemi will only run 6 or 4 cylinders if that is all that is needed, so you get V8 power when you want it, and 4 cylinder gas mileage when you need it.

For the 2007 Charger R/T AWD with the ~380 HP/~385 ft-lbs/torque 5.7L Hemi, the EPA estimated gas mileage is 17 in town and 24 on the highway, but generally it gets 20-22ish. That’s really good for such a powerful, large car, especially with the fuel-sucking AWD.

The SRT8 is all performance, so it has a lower 14 city/20 highway EPA estimate. It will get 15-16 if you drive it like you stole it, and you can squeak 20-22 out of it if you drive it conservatively. That’s what you get for a race car though.

Read full topic

item.title: Jaaa..new car
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

The Charger is fully loaded (navigation and everything), so I don’t think you would have sacrificed any luxuries. The only ‘sacrifice’ would be AWD, but it does have really good traction control. I wouldn’t drive it in the winter regardless, I have a nice vehicle for summer and a winter vehicle for winter. You can get an AWD charger, I’ll have to do some searching…

edit:
Here.
2007 Dodge Charger SXT $9,995
It’s got the small 3.5L V6 though, I’m not sure if they make an AWD model with a Hemi engine or not…
edit2:
2007 Dodge Charger 4dr Sdn 5-Spd Auto R/T AWD Sedan $15,750
Seems they did make them 2007 and up, that one looks like a REALLY GOOD deal! 2 years newer, basically same price (everyone takes less than asking), big ~380hp/torque Hemi, and AWD. Nice.

edit3:
I forgot to post the best stock option you can get for speed and snow:
2006 Jeep Grand Cherokee SRT-8 $22,000

That’s right, 425HP / 425 ft-lbs of torque, 6.1L Hemi with real 4 wheel drive, full out Brembo brakes, tuned suspension etc etc etc. Man that is sweet.

Read full topic

item.title: Jaaa..new car
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

The Charger doesnt look bad but I would have sacraficed alot of luxuries and handling + 1,000 more. I also need the AWD for winter when the roads are slick and its easy to get stuck. I don’t know how cheap a Charger AWD is but im guessing not what I payed.

Read full topic

item.title: Jaaa..new car
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Well I’m glad you like it, and I understand we like different types of cars, but just for comparison, this is what I would have rather had (both are a year newer than yours):

2006 Dodge Magnum R/T 5.7L V8 $7,995 <- Half your price
2006 Dodge Charger R/T HEMI $14,899 <- About the same price

Both of them have somewhere around 385 HP and 385 ft-lbs of torque, if you put a computer chip in there it makes both well over 400. They also have that cool multi-displacement thing where if you don’t need a bunch of power (idling, cruising at a certain speed), it can shut off some of the cylinders so you get the power of a 5.7 Hemi V8 with the fuel economy of a 4 cylinder. Plus it’s a Mopar, so you just can’t go wrong.

Read full topic

item.title: Jaaa..new car
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

Even the 2011 accords dont have keyless entry, keyless start, sh-awd, triptronic transmission, and most the other stuff on the RL. There is alot of other features I just dont have the time to list (or have I discovered them yet).

But to be honest the engine isnt weak or ‘tiny’ by no means its one of the fastest cars i’ve driven and it’s enough to beat any average person on the road or any ass who thinks his 1980’s mustang is the shit from the Staunchly american city I live in.

Also your right about the price I did pay 14,000 (13,965 + 35 administrative fees) but regardless of the license plates holder etc I didnt buy though the dealer I bought through them (for tax reasons) that I don’t want to go into details about. Also seeing that I got it so I cheap if I want to sell in 2-3 years I can probably get out with what I put in, seeing that when I sold my Acura MDX I profited 2,000 bought for 10,800 sold for 13,800 then paid 200 difference and sales tax and got a far better car than the base SUV that I had.

Read full topic

item.title: Jaaa..new car
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

If you wanted a Honda, you probably could have got the same thing a lot cheaper if it just said ‘Honda’ on it instead of ‘Acura’, since it’s the same thing.

Judging from the kbb value and what you said you paid under it, that tells me you paid about $14,000, which seems like a total rip off to me, you could have gotten much better for less I think. Anyway, tiny weak engine, not American, etc etc. You know I only like American cars, but hey, whatever floats your boat.

Read full topic
